articles.headline: High Schools Are Posting Their College Lists. Don’t Be Misled.
articles.snippet: The rosters showing where seniors are headed say little about the role that money and value played in their decisions.
articles.abstract: The rosters showing where seniors are headed say little about the role that money and value played in their decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once the first of May comes and goes, eagle-eyed observers in communities across the country await the list. Who is going where? How does it compare with last year — and other schools nearby? And what will it mean for private school applications next year, or real estate values or the college counselor’s standing?

articles.headline: Biden and Republicans Spar Over Unemployment as Job Gains Disappoint
articles.snippet: The president said he saw no measurable evidence that a $300 federal boost in unemployment benefits was hurting the labor market, amid criticism from conservatives and business groups.
articles.abstract: The president said he saw no measurable evidence that a $300 federal boost in unemployment benefits was hurting the labor market, amid criticism from conservatives and business groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disappointing jobs report released Friday by the Labor Department is posing the greatest test yet of President Biden’s strategy to revive the economy, with business groups and Republicans warning that the president’s policies are causing a labor shortage and that his broader agenda risks stoking runaway inflation.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Former Police Officers Indicted on Civil Rights Charges in George Floyd’s Death
articles.snippet: The indictment was a rare instance of police officers facing accusations of federal civil rights violations.
articles.abstract: The indictment was a rare instance of police officers facing accusations of federal civil rights violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four former Minneapolis police officers were indicted on federal charges unsealed on Friday of violating the civil rights of George Floyd, the Black man whose killing last year set off months of nationwide demonstrations against police violence.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Seized Washington Post’s Phone Records
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors sought phone records for three Washington Post journalists as part of an investigation into the publication of classified information in 2017.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors sought phone records for three Washington Post journalists as part of an investigation into the publication of classified information in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department under President Donald J. Trump secretly obtained the phone records for three reporters at The Washington Post from the early months of the Trump administration, the newspaper disclosed on Friday.

articles.headline: India and Its Vaccine Maker Stumble Over Their Pandemic Promises
articles.snippet: The Serum Institute vowed to protect the country from Covid-19 and inoculate the world’s poor, but India’s crisis has pushed it past its limits.
articles.abstract: The Serum Institute vowed to protect the country from Covid-19 and inoculate the world’s poor, but India’s crisis has pushed it past its limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Adar Poonawalla made big promises. The 40-year-old chief of the world’s largest vaccine maker pledged to take a leading role in the global effort to inoculate the poor against Covid-19. His India-based empire signed deals worth hundreds of millions of dollars to make and export doses to suffering countries.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh

articles.headline: Marooned at Mar-a-Lago, Trump Still Has Iron Grip on Republicans
articles.snippet: The vilification of Liz Cheney and a bizarre vote recount in Arizona showed the damage from his assault on a bedrock of democracy: election integrity.
articles.abstract: The vilification of Liz Cheney and a bizarre vote recount in Arizona showed the damage from his assault on a bedrock of democracy: election integrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Locked out of Facebook, marooned in Mar-a-Lago and mocked for an amateurish new website, Donald J. Trump remained largely out of public sight this week. Yet the Republican Party’s capitulation to the former president became clearer than ever, as did the damage to American politics he has caused with his lie that the election was stolen from him.

articles.headline: The Separate Worlds of Bill and Melinda Gates
articles.snippet: They built an empire that was essential in the pandemic. Now, their impending divorce makes personal a shift that confidants say was well underway in their philanthropic roles.
articles.abstract: They built an empire that was essential in the pandemic. Now, their impending divorce makes personal a shift that confidants say was well underway in their philanthropic roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates were stuck at home.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Rebecca R. Ruiz and David Gelles

articles.headline: Cyberattack Forces a Shutdown of a Top U.S. Pipeline
articles.snippet: The operator, Colonial Pipeline, said it had halted systems for its 5,500 miles of pipeline after being hit by a ransomware attack.
articles.abstract: The operator, Colonial Pipeline, said it had halted systems for its 5,500 miles of pipeline after being hit by a ransomware attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s largest pipelines, which carries refined gasoline and jet fuel from Texas up the East Coast to New York, was forced to shut down after being hit by ransomware in a vivid demonstration of the vulnerability of energy infrastructure to cyberattacks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Clifford Krauss and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: E-Commerce Mega-Warehouses, a Smog Source, Face New Pollution Rule
articles.snippet: A plan aimed at the nation’s largest cluster of warehouses is designed to spur electrification of pollution-spewing diesel trucks and could set a template for restrictions elsewhere.
articles.abstract: A plan aimed at the nation’s largest cluster of warehouses is designed to spur electrification of pollution-spewing diesel trucks and could set a template for restrictions elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southern California is home to the nation’s largest concentration of warehouses — a hub of thousands of mammoth structures, served by belching diesel trucks, that help feed America’s booming appetite for online shopping and also contribute to the worst air pollution in the country.

articles.headline: Bombing Outside Afghan School Kills at Least 90, With Girls as Targets
articles.snippet: The attack, which came at the end of a particularly violent week, underlined growing concerns about the American troop withdrawal.
articles.abstract: The attack, which came at the end of a particularly violent week, underlined growing concerns about the American troop withdrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Powerful explosions outside a high school in Afghanistan’s capital on Saturday killed at least 90 people and wounded scores more, many of them teenage girls leaving class, in a gruesome attack that underscored fears about the nation’s future after the impending American troop withdrawal.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Ma’Khia Bryant’s Journey Through Foster Care Ended With an Officer’s Bullet
articles.snippet: The 16-year-old girl was fatally shot while threatening a young woman with a knife. She had spent two years shuttling among Ohio foster homes, hoping to return to her mother.
articles.abstract: The 16-year-old girl was fatally shot while threatening a young woman with a knife. She had spent two years shuttling among Ohio foster homes, hoping to return to her mother.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The voice on the 911 call is a teenage girl’s, and it is quavering, as if she has been crying.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ellen Barry and Will Wright

articles.headline: Policymakers Used to Ignore Child Care. Then Came the Pandemic.
articles.snippet: Experts who sounded the alarm about the care economy were often shunted to the side of policy discussions. Not anymore.
articles.abstract: Experts who sounded the alarm about the care economy were often shunted to the side of policy discussions. Not anymore.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the economist Nancy Folbre got a call from the MacArthur Foundation in 1998, she was expecting rejection: a courtesy call to deny the funding application she’d submitted.

articles.headline: Online Cheating Charges Upend Dartmouth Medical School
articles.snippet: The university accused 17 students of cheating on remote exams, raising questions about data mining and sowing mistrust on campus.
articles.abstract: The university accused 17 students of cheating on remote exams, raising questions about data mining and sowing mistrust on campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — Sirey Zhang, a first-year student at Dartmouth’s Geisel School of Medicine, was on spring break in March when he received an email from administrators accusing him of cheating.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Schools Are Open, but Many Families Remain Hesitant to Return
articles.snippet: Even as fears of the coronavirus abate, many students are continuing to opt out of in-person learning. Some school leaders are trying to woo — or push — them back.
articles.abstract: Even as fears of the coronavirus abate, many students are continuing to opt out of in-person learning. Some school leaders are trying to woo — or push — them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pauline Rojas’s high school in San Antonio is open. But like many of her classmates, she has not returned, and has little interest in doing so.

articles.headline: Hacked Pipeline May Stay Shut for Days, Raising Concerns About Fuel Supply
articles.snippet: While the impact has been limited so far, some energy analysts warned of possible shortages and higher prices as the suspension continues.
articles.abstract: While the impact has been limited so far, some energy analysts warned of possible shortages and higher prices as the suspension continues.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The operator of the largest petroleum pipeline between Texas and New York, which was shut down after a ransomware attack, declined on Sunday to say when it would reopen, raising concerns about a critical piece of infrastructure that carries nearly half of the East Coast’s fuel supplies.

articles.headline: ‘Why Do We Deserve to Die?’ Kabul’s Hazaras Bury Their Daughters.
articles.snippet: A bomb attack that killed scores of schoolgirls, members of a long-persecuted minority, offered still more evidence that Afghanistan may be on the verge of unraveling.
articles.abstract: A bomb attack that killed scores of schoolgirls, members of a long-persecuted minority, offered still more evidence that Afghanistan may be on the verge of unraveling.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — One by one they brought the girls up the steep hill, shrouded bodies covered in a ceremonial prayer cloth, the pallbearers staring into the distance. Shouted prayers for the dead broke the silence.

articles.headline: As Scrutiny of Cryptocurrency Grows, the Industry Turns to K Street
articles.snippet: Companies behind digital currencies are rushing to hire well-connected lobbyists, lawyers and consultants as the battle over how to regulate them intensifies.
articles.abstract: Companies behind digital currencies are rushing to hire well-connected lobbyists, lawyers and consultants as the battle over how to regulate them intensifies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When federal regulators late last year accused one of the world’s most popular cryptocurrency platforms of illegally selling $1.38 billion worth of digital money to investors, it was a pivotal moment in efforts to crack down on a fast-growing market — and in the still-nascent industry’s willingness to dive deeply into the Washington influence game.

articles.headline: When Covid Hit, China Was Ready to Tell Its Version of the Story
articles.snippet: The government has been using its money and power to create an alternative to a global news media dominated by outlets like the BBC and CNN.
articles.abstract: The government has been using its money and power to create an alternative to a global news media dominated by outlets like the BBC and CNN.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2019, just before global borders closed, an international journalists’ association decided to canvass its members about a subject that kept coming up in informal conversations: What is China doing?

articles.headline: After Raid on Aqsa Mosque, Rockets From Gaza and Israeli Airstrikes
articles.snippet: Gaza officials say 20 people were killed in the airstrikes. The escalation followed clashes between the Israeli police and Palestinian protesters at Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: Gaza officials say 20 people were killed in the airstrikes. The escalation followed clashes between the Israeli police and Palestinian protesters at Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Weeks of simmering tensions in Jerusalem between Palestinian protesters, the police and right-wing Israelis suddenly veered into military conflict on Monday, as a local skirmish in the decades-long battle for control of the city escalated into rocket fire and airstrikes in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: China Targets Muslim Women in Push to Suppress Births in Xinjiang
articles.snippet: In most of China, women are being urged to have more babies to shore up a falling birthrate. But in Xinjiang, they are being forced to have fewer.
articles.abstract: In most of China, women are being urged to have more babies to shore up a falling birthrate. But in Xinjiang, they are being forced to have fewer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When China’s government ordered women in her mostly Muslim community in the region of Xinjiang to be fitted with contraceptive devices, Qelbinur Sedik pleaded for an exemption. She was nearly 50 years old, she told officials. She had obeyed the government’s birth limits and had only one child.

articles.headline: Complaint Accuses Mexican Factories of Labor Abuses, Testing New Trade Pact
articles.snippet: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other groups are seeking to make use of a new enforcement mechanism in the updated North American trade deal.
articles.abstract: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other groups are seeking to make use of a new enforcement mechanism in the updated North American trade deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other groups filed a complaint with the Biden administration on Monday over claims of labor violations at a group of auto parts factories in Mexico, a move that will pose an early test of the new North American trade deal and its labor protections.
